title: Question 20

children: A 39-year-old woman is evaluated because of a 9-month history of cough occurring during the day but especially at night. She has to clear her throat often. She has no postnasal drip, acid reflux symptoms, dyspnea, or wheezing. She has never smoked cigarettes and takes no medications.
Physical examination shows cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx. Chest radiograph is normal.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

Upper airway cough syndrome is the most common cause of chronic cough (>8 weeks' duration); other common causes of chronic cough include asthma, gastroesophageal reflux disease, ACE inhibitors, and smoking.
Guidelines recommend initiating therapy for upper airway cough syndrome as the first management step in patients with undifferentiated cough syndrome.
The most appropriate treatment is diphenhydramine and pseudoephedrine (

). This patient most likely has upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), the most common cause of chronic cough (>8 weeks' duration). Other common causes of chronic cough include asthma, gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), ACE inhibitors, and smoking. UACS was previously known as postnasal drip syndrome, but the name was revised to include other etiologies that cause excess upper airway secretions. Symptoms of UACS include cough, nasal discharge, sensation of postnasal drip, or frequent throat clearing, although symptoms other than cough are not always present. The oropharyngeal examination in UACS may reveal cobblestoning of the posterior pharynx or visible mucopurulent secretions draining from the nasopharynx. Allergic rhinitisâ€“associated UACS is optimally treated with intranasal glucocorticoids, whereas UACS resulting from nonallergic rhinitis responds best to first-generation antihistamines (chlorpheniramine, brompheniramine, diphenhydramine) and decongestants (pseudoephedrine).
GERD is also a common source of chronic cough. For patients with undifferentiated cough, a trial of empiric GERD treatment with a proton pump inhibitor (PPI), such as lansoprazole (

), is reasonable, but guidelines suggest first initiating empiric trials of therapy for UACS, then asthma. This patient does not have signs or symptoms of GERD for which a PPI would be indicated as initial therapy.

Asthma should be considered in patients with symptoms that do not respond to empiric treatment for UACS. Cough-variant asthma is diagnosed if spirometry and/or bronchial hyperresponsiveness testing results with an agent such as methacholine (

) are abnormal and symptoms improve with standard therapy for asthma, including inhaled glucocorticoids. For patients with undifferentiated cough without features or testing to suggest a specific diagnosis, empiric asthma therapy can be considered, but guidelines recommend this only after empiric therapy for UACS has been trialed.

In patients with normal findings on evaluation or failed empiric treatment for UACS, asthma, and GERD, the most reasonable next step is to exclude nonasthmatic eosinophilic bronchitis with sputum analysis for eosinophils (
) or exhaled nitric oxide testing. If test results are abnormal, therapy with inhaled glucocorticoids should be initiated.

references: Irwin RS, French CL, Chang AB, et al; CHEST Expert Cough Panel*. Classification of cough as a symptom in adults and management algorithms: CHEST guideline and expert panel report. Chest. 2018;153:196-209.
